title: What makes a good horror movie, the story or how scary it is? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m always going to prefer a good story first, after all that is the whole point of a movie. Of course, I would love some good scares since it is a horror movie but a well done story can be forgiven weak scares. A terrible or nonexistent story, even with stellar effects and excellent scares, still poses a problem. If it’s really good, sequels will probably follow, is it even possible to have sequels without a story? And once there are fans, fans require lore! What’s going on? What’s the backstory and where are we going with this? A few days ago, I was talking about this very thing with Jeepers Creepers[1].  Great monster, great effects and we have the  rules for the monster and the sequel is just as good and can be watched right after the first because it’s like one long movie but 3 movies in and a 4th on the horizon. Some story needs to be forthcoming otherwise, the franchise will lose the fan base, they will cease to care. And the lack of a story made the missteps in the 3rd movie, unforgivable. That’s also an issue of no story, in the absense of story, shortcomings are glaring. And where fans would normally make excuses for them, had there been decent lore, but because there isn’t, there’s just nothing to defend. The movie makers have only given us a monster, effects and kills, effectively painting themselves in a corner. Now the quality better only get better otherwise, it’ll be playing to an empty room. Footnotes[1] Macabre...ish Horror Review: Jeepers Creepers

The answer is going to be a combination of the two. It’s not enough for a horror film to be “scary.” That’s because a jump scare is among the easiest to pull off: the camera is a little off-kilter, and then—BOOM!—someone comes out of nowhere (which surprises the protagonist, and us). There’s a clever edit, and a stern strain of violins, and the scare is achieved. Bravo. But such scares are cheap. To have a good, quality scare, the scare must come about organically, from the story itself. And then it must make leaps of unpredictability that surprise the viewer, clobbering him into submission. As I am writing this, I am thinking about “Let the Right One In,” one of the last truly impressive horror movies since the turn of the century. The final moments of that film, (don’t worry, I won’t spoil anything here), are as creative and as terrifying as can be. The final moments happen organically, as a result of a powerful story where you grow to care for the two young leads. Had the movie begun on such a note, the impact would not nearly have been so strong.

The storyline, whether it’s realistic or outrageous, I like when horror movies are psychological when you don’t actually see the blood, guts, and gore. For example, Rosemarys baby, The Blair Witch project, The innocents, Jacobs ladder, the changeling etc. I find them to be the best my favorite genre of horror supernatural, occult, psychological, And always classic horror. Never got scared from Freddy, Jason or Michael. Slasher films don’t do it for me. But everyone’s different Try faces of Death
